measured_by: non-luminance–mediated changes in pupil size / baseline-corrected pupil dilation
justification: The article states that “The activity of brainstem arousal systems can be tracked non-invasively by measuring nonluminance-mediated changes in pupil size,” indicating that variations in pupil diameter are used as the instrument to capture arousal.

During the slider phase, “participants reported their reward probability estimate with a slider ranging from 0 to 100. The reported reward probability reflected the participants’ updated belief,” showing that the slider scale operationalises the belief construct.

The authors note that they “induced uncertainty… by manipulating contrast-difference levels… Belief states were more uncertain when contrast differences were smaller,” establishing contrast difference as the quantitative measure of uncertainty.

measured_by: trial-by-trial belief updates derived from slider responses divided by prediction error
justification: They explain that “The learning rate (LR) is then computed as the extent to which participants updated their belief about the reward probability for that trial's prediction error,” indicating that the calculated LR from belief updates is the metric for the learning-rate construct.
